title: What is the force acting on a body when it is lifted, and how is it different from pulling or pushing the object? - Quora

response.answer_text: A ‘lifting’ force is countered by a gravitational force. If the lifting force is greater than the weight of the object- the object will move upward. One can also ‘Pull’ up or ‘push’ up but pull/push can also be ascribed to forces that act horizontally (perpendicular to a gravitational force). So, ‘lifting’ is reserved for forces acting opposite gravity.

Let the wt. of the body = Mg, and the lifting force be F.e of attraction down Then when it is lifted the force upward is F and the force of attraction is Mg downwards. The resultant force is | F - Mg|. If there be friction while pulling or pushing force is P (horizontally) then the resultant force acting on the body will be |P - mu. R| where R is the normal reaction on the body = Mg.
